title: Assignment01
text:
Run Fall.R (on class GitHub under R)



Give your own colors (e.g. Spring).
Export the file and post on your GitHub website.


# Title Fall color
# Credit: https://fronkonstin.com

# Install packages

#install.packages("gsubfn")
#install.packages("tidyverse")
library(gsubfn)

Warning: package 'gsubfn' was built under R version 4.1.3


Loading required package: proto

library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.1.3


-- Attaching packages --------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.3.2 --


v ggplot2 3.3.5     v purrr   0.3.4
v tibble  3.1.6     v dplyr   1.0.7
v tidyr   1.1.4     v stringr 1.4.0
v readr   2.1.1     v forcats 0.5.1


-- Conflicts ------------------------------------------ tidyverse_conflicts() --
x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
x dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

# Define elements in plant art
# Each image corresponds to a different axiom, rules, angle and depth

# Leaf of Fall

axiom="X"
rules=list("X"="F-[[X]+X]+F[+FX]-X", "F"="FF")
angle=22.5
depth=6


for (i in 1:depth) axiom=gsubfn(".", rules, axiom)

actions=str_extract_all(axiom, "\\d*\\+|\\d*\\-|F|L|R|\\[|\\]|\\|") %>% unlist

status=data.frame(x=numeric(0), y=numeric(0), alfa=numeric(0))
points=data.frame(x1 = 0, y1 = 0, x2 = NA, y2 = NA, alfa=90, depth=1)


# Generating data
# Note: may take a minute or two

for (action in actions)
{
  if (action=="F")
  {
    x=points[1, "x1"]+cos(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    y=points[1, "y1"]+sin(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    points[1,"x2"]=x
    points[1,"y2"]=y
    data.frame(x1 = x, y1 = y, x2 = NA, y2 = NA,
               alfa=points[1, "alfa"],
               depth=points[1,"depth"]) %>% rbind(points)->points
  }
  if (action %in% c("+", "-")){
    alfa=points[1, "alfa"]
    points[1, "alfa"]=eval(parse(text=paste0("alfa",action, angle)))
  }
  if(action=="["){
    data.frame(x=points[1, "x1"], y=points[1, "y1"], alfa=points[1, "alfa"]) %>%
      rbind(status) -> status
    points[1, "depth"]=points[1, "depth"]+1
  }

  if(action=="]"){
    depth=points[1, "depth"]
    points[-1,]->points
    data.frame(x1=status[1, "x"], y1=status[1, "y"], x2=NA, y2=NA,
               alfa=status[1, "alfa"],
               depth=depth-1) %>%
      rbind(points) -> points
    status[-1,]->status
  }
}

ggplot() +
  geom_segment(aes(x = x1, y = y1, xend = x2, yend = y2),
               lineend = "round",
               color="red1", # Set your own Fall color?
               data=na.omit(points)) +
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1) +
  theme_void() # No grid nor axes





Write a critique on a chart in published work (book/article/news website).
‘Misleading Statistics’
Scales on Y-axis (no defined) distort the results.
https://www.datapine.com/blog/misleading-statistics-and-data/

title: Assignment03
text:
Compare the regression models
Compare different ways to create the plots(e.g. changing colors, line types, plot characters)


Can you finetune the charts without using other packages (consult RGraphics by Murrell)
How about with ggplot2?(use tidyverse package)

title: Assignment04
text:
# Data Visualization
# Assignment 4-1

# Set Column Names
df <- data.frame(x = c("Texas", "Florida", "NewYork",
     "California"), width = c(25, 50, 75, 100), height = c(100,
     75, 50, 25))

df$w <- cumsum(df$width)
df$wm <- df$w - df$width
df$wt <- with(df, wm + (w - wm)/2)

library(ggplot2)
p <- ggplot(df, aes(ymin = 0))
p1 <- p + geom_rect(aes(xmin = wm, xmax = w,
     ymax = height, fill = x))

p2 <- p1 + geom_text(aes(x = wt, y = height *
     0.5, label = x))

p2 + ggtitle("Carbon Emission and Gas Price by State") + xlab("Gas Price") + ylab("Carbon Emission")




The figure above shows the relationship between carbon emissions and gas prices by state. California has the highest gas price and the least carbon emission. On the other hand, Texas has the least gas price while the highest carbon emission. The figure illustrates that the higher the gas price, the lower the carbon emissions.

title: Assignment04
text:
2. Table with Embedded Charts

# Data Visualization
# Assignment 4-2

# Creating Table with Embedded Charts
carbon <- read.csv("carbon.csv", header=TRUE)
head(carbon)

    ï..State PerCapitaEmission CarbonIntensity Region           Division
1    Alabama         21.648482        433.6878   West            Pacific
2     Alaska         46.674987        643.1302  South East South Central
3    Arizona         12.690212        239.3805  South West South Central
4   Arkansas         21.539954        500.0933   West           Mountain
5 California          9.081707        140.3001   West            Pacific
6   Colorado         15.930418        263.3013   West           Mountain

x dplyr::lag()       masks stats::lag()
x dplyr::src()       masks Hmisc::src()
x dplyr::summarize() masks Hmisc::summarize()

library(ggplot2)

# Calucating Mean
mean(carbon$PerCapitaEmission)

[1] 20.29298



# Creating Dummy Variable
carbon$PerCapitaEmission_dummy <- ifelse(carbon$PerCapitaEmission>=20.20489, 1, 0)

# Creating Ordinal Variable
carbon$CarbonIntensity_ordinal <- cut2(carbon$CarbonIntensity, m=10)

# 
table(carbon$PerCapitaEmission_dummy, carbon$CarbonIntensity_ordinal)

   
    [ 71.2, 197) [196.6, 270) [269.6, 342) [342.4, 500) [500.1,1035]
  0           11           10           10            3            0
  1            0            0            0            7           10



carbon_df <- data.frame(carbon)

# Code below does not work...

title: Assignment 4
text:
# Data Visualization
# Assignment 4-1

# Set Column Names
df <- data.frame(x = c("Texas", "Florida", "NewYork",
     "California"), width = c(25, 50, 75, 100), height = c(100,
     75, 50, 25))

df$w <- cumsum(df$width)
df$wm <- df$w - df$width
df$wt <- with(df, wm + (w - wm)/2)

library(ggplot2)
p <- ggplot(df, aes(ymin = 0))
p1 <- p + geom_rect(aes(xmin = wm, xmax = w,
     ymax = height, fill = x))

p2 <- p1 + geom_text(aes(x = wt, y = height *
     0.5, label = x))

p2 + ggtitle("Carbon Emission and Gas Price by State") + xlab("Gas Price") + ylab("Carbon Emission")




The figure above shows the relationship between carbon emissions and gas prices by state. California has the highest gas price and the least carbon emission. On the other hand, Texas has the least gas price while the highest carbon emission. The figure illustrates that the higher the gas price, the lower the carbon emissions.
